hook.text: Fiat-backed stablecoins are simple: for every token in circulation, one real dollar sits in a bank account.

buildup.text: When you buy a USDC, Circle puts one dollar into reserves. When you redeem, they destroy the token and return the dollar.

discovery.text: The reserves are audited regularly to prove the dollars actually exist. Transparency builds trust.

twist.text: Not all fiat-backed stablecoins hold only cash. Some hold bonds, loans, and other assets that are harder to liquidate.

climax.text: Fiat-backed stablecoins are the simplest and most trusted. They're also the most centralized â€” one company controls everything.

punchline.text: Real dollars in a real bank. The simplest stablecoin is also the most centralized.

quiz.question: What backs a fiat-backed stablecoin?
options: Real dollars or equivalent assets held in reserve accounts
